These methods of examination are also used to examine sea cargo containers in those ports that do not have a CEF.

Since July 2002 Customs has significantly increased its level of intervention in air cargo (including 100 per cent of reportable documents in the High-Volume-Low-Value (HVLV) stream). Customs examines air cargo using x-ray, detector dogs, ion scan or physical inspection. Customs also examines 100 per cent of incoming postal articles. Customs has deployed radiation pagers to be worn by officers involved in examining air cargo to detect radiological threats.

Customs has been working in conjunction with the Commonwealth Scientific an Industrial research Organisation (CSIRO) to develop technology to inspect air cargo. The Government has recently announced additional funding to conduct a field trial of this new freight screening technology to assess its suitability for use within the Australian aviation sector.

Customs will construct a facility in Brisbane to trial world-first neutron technology developed by CSIRO that promises rapid detection of explosives and other threats in air cargo more effectively than conventional x-ray systems. The technology is non-intrusive, minimising the impact of security on the rapid movement demanded by the air freight industry. It is estimated the technology will scan an air freight container in less than two minutes. Import and export air cargo containers in Brisbane are to be screened at the facility.

Customs has significantly increased its boarding of first port of arrival vessels from 44 per cent in 2001-2002 to 68 per cent in 2002-2003. In the first quarter of this year, Customs first port of arrival boarding reached a high of 72 per cent. This increased level of boarding is in response to the changed security environment and the recognition that some vessels and crew could pose a greater risk than they did in the past. Crew lists for all vessels arriving in Australia are screened and risk assessed.
Part (b)

The Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS) will be regulating certain maritime industry participants in the maritime transport sector on passage of the Maritime Transport Security Bill 2003 (MTSB) through Parliament. The MTSB gives effect to new international maritime security requirements embedded in the amendments to the Safety of Life at Sea Convention and the new International Ship and Port Facility Security Code, which comes into effect on July 1 2004.

The objective of the MTSB is to establish a regulatory framework for preventive security at up to 70 ports and 300 port facilities around Australia. It will also apply to 70 Australian flagged ships and certain classes of foreign flagged ships in Australian waters. The MTSB is designed to complement Customs risk assessment of passengers, cargo and vessels within the port environment and other important border protection legislation.

Customs has stepped up its surveillance at sea ports by initiating a program of 24-hour ports patrols, increased use of closed-circuit television and pursuing pre-arrival information about vessels and crew. Customs now monitors 56 port areas and 88 separate wharves around Australia 24 hours a day, seven days a week, using a sophisticated national closed circuit television networks.

The capacity for Customs to respond to cargo presenting a threat has been strengthened by the introduction of powers to seize in-transit cargo under the Border Security Legislation Amendment Act 2002 (the Act). Under the Act,
in-transit cargo connected with the carrying out of a terrorist act or presenting a threat to Australia's defence or security, or international peace or security can be seized on issue of a warrant.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) In respect of the sale of the Bankstown, Hoxton Park and Camden airports, (a) what was the sale price, (b) what are the terms of payment, and (c) what will the Government receive after settling any potential liabilities relating to the operation of the airports.
(2) What are the sale guidelines relating to the potential for commercial development of the three airports and how will the guidelines apply in terms of the operation of the Airports Act.
(3) When will Hoxton Park revert to freehold.
(4) Will there be any consultation with the NSW Government and Liverpool Council concerning commercial development of the site in the period leading up to the airport becoming freehold.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The sale price was $211 millionârounded and excluding GST. (b) The sale price was paid in full on 15 December 2003. (c) The Government received $211 millionârounded and excluding GST. Post sale liabilities are being met by the new owner.
(2) The regulatory regime established under the Airports Act 1996, which applied to the airports prior to sale, continues to apply after the sale.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 24 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2477 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22592), in respect of the procedures in place by the (a) Department of Education, Science and Training, (b) CSIRO, (c) Australian Institute of Marine Science, (d) Anglo-Australian Telescope Board, (e) Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, (f) Australian National Training Authority, and (g) Australian National University to prevent the engagement of legal practitioners who use insolvency as a means of avoiding paying tax, are these procedures enforceable at law by (i) him, (ii) the agency, or (iii) any other person; if so, who.

(2) If the procedures are enforceable at law, what provisions apply; if no powers exist to enforce the policies because they are non-compellable powers, why are the powers contained in these policies non-compellable.

(3) Is he able to say how many legal practitioners in the financial years ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003 were not retained on the grounds of their insolvency by agencies within his portfolio.

(4) Is he able to say how many legal practitioners in the financial years ended 30 June (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003 were retained irrespective of their being found to have been insolvent by those agencies.
(5) If previously insolvent legal practitioners were retained by the agencies within his portfolio, on what basis was this permitted.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: In March 2001, the previous Attorney-General wrote to Ministers of the day asking that their departments and agencies not engage counsel who use insolvency as a means of avoiding paying tax. As this request was restricted to barristers and not to solicitors, my response is therefore restricted to the engagement of barristers.

(1) The procedures adopted by my Department and portfolio agencies give effect to the previous Attorney-General's request. Regulation 9 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations 1997 requires approvers of proposals to spend public moneys to be satisfied that the proposed expenditure is in accordance with the policies of the Commonwealth. My Department and portfolio agencies comply with this requirement.
(2) See the answer to (1) above.
(5) Based upon the answer to (4) above, not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2186 (Hansard, 13 October 2003, page 21279) in respect of the application of section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (ADJR) to decisions of an administrative character under the Migration Act 1958 that are not privative clause decisions within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act, is the Minister aware of the judgment of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598.

(2) Notwithstanding the privative clause provision in section 474 of the Migration Act, does section 5 still permit judicial review of decisions in which it can be established that there exists (a) Jurisdictional error, (b) Mala Fides, and (c) Constitutional Grounds.
(3) Are there any other grounds known to the Minister in which the provisions of section 5 of the ADJR Act apply notwithstanding the provision of section 474 Migration Act; if so, what are they.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the decision of the High Court of Australia in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598.

(2) and (3) Paragraph (da) of Schedule 1 to the ADJR Act excludes a privative clause decision within the meaning of subsection 474(2) of the Migration Act from those decisions to which the ADJR Act applies. This has the effect of restricting the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the Federal Magistrates Court under the ADJR Act in respect of migration decisions to those decisions set out in subsection 474(4) of the Migration Act and any decisions specified in regulation made under subsection 474(5). Whether a particular decision made under the Migration Act would be excluded from judicial review would be a matter for the Court to determine.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 2 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Is he aware that from 1 October 2003 SBS began digital transmission from Bendigo on Channel 28.
(2) Was he or his department warned of the potential for co-channel interference with the analogue signal from Mt Dandenong which is also on Channel 28.
(3) Is he aware that co-channel interference has prevented some constituents in the Romsey area, in the electoral division of Burke, receiving SBS.
(4) What steps does he intend to take to rectify this problem and allow SBS coverage to be restored to the area.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The official `on-air' date for the transmission of SBS' digital television service to Bendigo on UHF channel 28 was 1 November 2003, however, test transmissions of this service commenced from 1 October 2003. It is standard practice to test broadcasting services in advance of their official `on-air' date.

(2) No. The potential for co-channel interference between the Bendigo SBS digital service and the Melbourne SBS analog service was not identified in the Australian Broadcasting Authority's relevant Digital Channel Plan as an expected phenomenon. As such, I am advised that SBS did not advise the previous Minister of this potential when it submitted its implementation plan for the extension of its digital service to Bendigo to him for approval.

(3) I was not aware of any SBS reception problems in the Romsey area prior to the Member for Burke raising the matter in Parliament. Subsequent investigations have revealed that, as at 11 December 2003, neither the Department of Commun-ications, Information Technology and the Arts, the Australian Broadcasting Authority nor SBS have received any written complaints from Romsey residents (who, I understand, number about 3000) regarding this matter. SBS did, however, indicate that it had received two telephone complaints that appeared to be directly related to the situation the Member for Burke has described.
(4) I am advised by SBS that no changes are planned in relation to SBS' current television transmission arrangements for Bendigo and Melbourne.

While the Australian Broadcasting Authority has suggested SBS could consider reducing the power of its Bendigo digital service towards Romsey or seek a new channel for the service, the disadvantages associated with these options would appear to significantly outweigh any benefit the two known complainants would derive. The Bendigo digital service is intended to serve in excess of 68,000 people. A reduction in power or channel change for this service is likely to result in a reduced number of people being able to access SBS' digital service. SBS believes that channel 28 represents the best channel available for its digital service from a coverage perspective.

In Victoria, available channels are limited because of the number of television services throughout the populated areas. While every effort has been made by the Australian Broadcasting Authority to minimise interference, it has not been possible to remove all potential for interference to occur during the simulcast period due to spectrum scarcity. (The simulcast period is the period in which both analog and digital television services are transmitted within a market (and, potentially, adjacent markets) prior to the analog service being eventually switched off.) The co-channel interference some Romsey residents are currently experiencing will not be present when the conversion to digital television transmission is completed and SBS' Melbourne analog service is switched off.

SBS has suggested that affected residents should consult a local antenna technician about what options are available for restoring their SBS reception. It has further suggested that such residents might wish to consider purchasing or renting a receiver that would enable them to watch SBS' Melbourne digital television service on channel 29. Should the Member for Burke's constituents have any queries in relation to this advice, I would suggest that they contact SBS on 1800 500 727 (freecall - asking for Transmission Services) between 9am and 5pm AEST Monday to Friday.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2339 (Hansard, 2 December 2003, page 23139), for the purposes of Schedule 3 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 is (a) cat fur and, (b) dog fur an item on that Schedule; if so, (i) what is the dutiable amount of each type of fur under that Schedule, and (ii) why is cat and dog fur so scheduled.

(2) Does he intend to have cat and dog fur prohibited, either in itself or as part of a product including apparel, under the provisions of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations 1956; if so when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) There are no items in Schedule 3 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 that specifically identify whether or not goods comprise, or contain, dog or cat fur.

There are two tariff items for tanned or dressed furskins and raw furskins. The rate of duty for tanned or dressed furskins, which can include cat or dog fur, is 5 percent. There is no duty applicable to raw furskins.

If dog or cat fur were incorporated into other articles including apparel and ornaments, such articles would be classified to the relevant tariff item in accordance with tariff classification rules and would attract the applicable rate of duty.

(2) The Government considers that a ban on the importation of products with cat and dog fur may be the right approach, but it would be sensible to have a consistent framework across Australia for dealing with any infringements.
There are still a number of issues to be resolved and these are being worked through by officials from relevant portfoliosâthe Government will consider the outcome carefully.
